questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents after a motor vehicle accident with a clavicle fracture. During surgery, the surgeon carefully avoids damaging nearby blood vessels, including those from the thyrocervical trunk. Which artery is not a branch of the thyrocervical trunk and is less likely to be encountered during this procedure?

A 40-year-old man undergoes surgery for a tumour in the axilla. During the procedure, the surgeon identifies the second part of the axillary artery and its branches. Which of the following arteries arises from this segment of the axillary artery and must be carefully preserved during the dissection?
The following image illustrates the blood supply to the mammary gland. Identify the artery labelled "A."
questions.explanation:
Blood supply of the Mammary gland

Source of Blood Supply

Arteries

Description

Internal Thoracic Artery (Option B)

Medial Mammary Branches

Originates from the subclavian artery and supplies the anteromedial part of the breast.

Axillary Artery

Lateral Thoracic Artery (Option A)

It gives off lateral mammary branches to supply the lateral aspect of the breast.

Subscapular Artery (Option D)

Contributes to the blood supply to lateral and posterior aspects of the breast

Anterior Intercostal Arteries (Option C)

2nd to 4th Intercostal Arteries

Enlarges during lactation; Supplies superior regions of the breast

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a shoulder injury following a fall. During a physical examination, the physician palpates the brachial artery to assess the blood supply to the arm. At which anatomical landmark does this artery begin as a continuation of the axillary artery?

options.label: A
options.text: Lower border of the teres minor

options.label: B
options.text: Upper border of the teres major

options.label: C
options.text: Lower border of the teres major

options.label: D
options.text: Upper border of the teres minor

questions.correct_answer: C. Lower border of the teres major
questions.explanation:
Brachial Artery

Aspect

Description

Origin

Continuation of the axillary artery at the inferior border of the teres major muscle.

Course
  • Courses distally, spiralling from medial to anterior, lying midway between the medial and lateral epicondyles of the humerus.
  • Terminates about 1 cm distal to the elbow into radial and ulnar arteries.

Major Branches
  • Profunda Brachii Artery: Supplies posterior compartment muscles.
  • Nutrient Artery: Supplies the humerus.
  • Superior Ulnar Collateral Artery: Anastomoses with posterior ulnar recurrent artery.
  • Inferior Ulnar Collateral Artery: Anastomoses with anterior ulnar recurrent artery.
  • Deltoid Artery: Supplies the deltoid muscle.
  • Muscular Arteries: Supply various arm muscles.
  • Radial Artery: Supplies the lateral forearm and contributes to the palmar arch.
  • Ulnar Artery: Supplies the medial forearm and contributes to the palmar arch.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with intermittent pain and numbness in his right hand, especially after gripping. The physician suspects vascular insufficiency. Which test is the physician likely to perform to assess the blood supply to the hand?

A 72-year-old male with a history of atherosclerosis and hypertension presents with sudden severe pain, numbness, and weakness in his left arm. Examination shows difficulty gripping and sensory loss in the hand. Which anastomosis is most critical for collateral blood flow to the left upper limb in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Suprascapular artery and dorsal scapular artery

options.label: B
options.text: Subscapular artery and circumflex scapular artery

options.label: C
options.text: Superior thoracic artery and acromiothoracic artery

options.label: D
options.text: Suprascapular artery and circumflex scapular artery

questions.correct_answer: D. Suprascapular artery and circumflex scapular artery
questions.explanation:
Around the body of the scapula

Over the acromion process
  • Suprascapular artery (branch of the thyrocervical trunk)
  • Circumflex scapular artery (branch of the subscapular artery from the 3rd part of the axillary artery)
  • Deep branch of the transverse cervical artery (branch of the thyrocervical trunk).
  • Acromial branch of the thoracoacromial artery (2nd part of axillary).
  • Acromial branch of the suprascapular artery (1st part of subclavian).
  • Acromial branch of the posterior circumflex humeral artery (3rd part of axillary).

questions.text: A patient with stage 5 chronic kidney disease is preparing for hemodialysis. During the examination, tenderness is noted in the right arm, and a prominent vein is visible. The doctor asks the intern to identify the vein, hinting that it pierces the clavipectoral fascia. What vein is being referenced?

A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic following her mammogram results, revealing a palpable mass in her left breast and mild discomfort. Examination shows enlarged lymph nodes in the left axilla. Which of the following is the terminal group of axillary lymph nodes?
questions.explanation:
Lymph Nodes/Plexus

Part of breast

Anterior axillary or pectoral group of lymph nodes (Option B)

Lateral quadrants

Internal mammary lymph nodes

Medial quadrants

Posterior intercostal nodes

Lower lateral quadrant

Subdiaphragmatic and subperitoneal lymph plexuses

Lower medial quadrant

Apical group of axillary lymph nodes (Option C)

Deep surface

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with swelling and pain in his right hand, particularly around the base of the thumb, after puncturing it with a nail. Examination shows tenderness, swelling, and limited thumb movement. An infection is diagnosed. Which statement about this space is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: Infection can spread through the radial bursa

options.label: C
options.text: Associated short muscles of thumb anteriorly

options.label: D
options.text: Anterior wall is formed by the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th lumbricals

questions.correct_answer: D. Anterior wall is formed by the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th lumbricals
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Midpalmar Space

Thenar Space

Shape

Triangular

Triangular (Option A)

Site

Under the inner half of the hollow of the palm

Under the outer half of the hollow of the palm

Extent

  • Distal margin of the flexor retinaculum (proximal)
  • Distal palmar crease (distal)
  • Distal margin of the flexor retinaculum (proximal)
  • Proximal transverse palmar crease (distal)

Communications
  • Forearm space of Parona (proximal)
  • Fascial sheaths of the 3rd and 4th lumbricals (distal)
  • Forearm space of Parona (proximal)
  • The fascial sheath of the first lumbrical (distal)

Anterior wall
  • Palmar aponeurosis
  • Flexor tendons of 3rd, 4th and 5th digits
  • Medial three (2nd, 3rd, and 4th) lumbricals (Option D)
  • Short muscles of the thumb (Option C)
  • Flexor tendons of the index finger
  • 1st lumbrical
  • Palmar aponeurosis

Posterior wall

Fascia covering interossei and metacarpals

Transverse head of adductor pollicis

Lateral wall

Intermediate palmar septum
  • Tendon of flexor pollicis longus with radial bursa
  • Lateral palmar septum

Medial wall

Medial palmar septum

Intermediate palmar septum

Infection inlet

Ulnar bursa
  • Radial bursa (Option B)
  • Synovial sheath of the index finger

Incision for drainage

3rd or 4th web space

1st web (posteriorly)

questions.text: A teenager presents with severe pain and swelling in the tip of her right index finger after slamming it into a door. Examination reveals significant swelling, erythema, tenderness, increased sensitivity, and difficulty moving the finger. An infection of the structure marked ‘X’ is diagnosed. What is most likely?

A 45-year-old patient is undergoing surgery on the forearm. During the procedure, the surgeon ligates the brachial artery near the elbow. Which anastomotic site helps maintain blood flow to the forearm?

options.label: A
options.text: In front of the lateral epicondyle

options.label: C
options.text: In front of the medial epicondyle

questions.correct_answer: C. In front of the medial epicondyle

questions.text: A patient sustains a deep laceration to the palm, resulting in significant bleeding. The surgeon identifies damage to an arterial structure located superficial to the flexor tendons and supplying the medial 3½ digits. Which arterial structure is most likely injured?
questions.explanation:
Superficial Palmar Arch

Deep Palmar Arch

Anastomosis

Between ulnar and radial arteries.

Between radial and ulnar arteries.

Location
  • Deep to palmaris brevis and aponeurosis.
  • Crosses palm over flexor tendons and median nerve

Deep to flexor tendons, on proximal metacarpals and interossei.

Formed by

Ulnar artery (superficial branch) and radial artery (superficial branch).

Radial artery (terminal part) and ulnar artery (deep branch).

Branches
  • Three common digital arteries (medial 3½ digits).
  • One proper digital branch.
  • Lateral digital branches join palmar metacarpal arteries from deep arch.
  • Three palmar metacarpal arteries (supply medial metacarpals).
  • Three perforating digital arteries (anastomose with dorsal metacarpal arteries).
  • Recurrent branch (supplies carpal bones and joints, ends in palmar carpal arch).

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with weakness in thumb flexion and loss of forearm pronation after a deep laceration to the anterior forearm. Imaging reveals disruption of an artery accompanying the anterior interosseous nerve. Which artery is most likely damaged?
Which of the following statements regarding the median cubital vein is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: It connects the cephalic vein to the basilic vein.

options.label: B
options.text: It runs obliquely downward and laterally across the forearm.

options.label: C
options.text: It is superficial to the bicipital aponeurosis, which separates it from the brachial artery.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the primary choice for venipuncture and catheterization due to its stability.

questions.correct_answer: B. It runs obliquely downward and laterally across the forearm.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with breast cancer presents with enlarged lymph nodes in her axilla. Biopsy reveals metastatic spread. Which group of axillary lymph nodes is most likely the initial site of cancer drainage?
